Dear Amanda Garza:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact the area
manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 – Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/10/23, youth stole the facility vehicle while at the movies with
staff. Staff had placed the keys in the cupholder. Youth asked to
go to the bathroom and when youth did not return staff saw the
vehicle was missing. LE was contacted and OnStar was able to
disable the vehicle.
Investigation On 06/14/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Youth A at
Ingham County Youth Center. DHHS specialist was also present
for the interview. She reported staff from Footprints had come to
see her yesterday to discuss what had occurred when she was at
the movies with the staff. Youth A reported she was at Ingham
County Youth Center because she stole the agency vehicle.
Youth A reported she was taken to the movies by Staff 1 and it
was just the two of them that attended. About an hour into the
movie, Youth A reported she asked to go to the restroom and was
allowed to go alone and returned after a few minutes. Youth A
reported Staff 1 gave her the keys, her wallet and telephone to
hold in her purse as Staff 1 did not have anywhere to store the
items in. Youth A reported after another 30 minutes, she asked to
go to the restroom again and was allowed to go alone. She stated
she realized Staff 1 had taken the phone and wallet from her
purse but left the vehicle keys. Youth A stated after using the
restroom, she contemplated stealing the car for about 15 minutes.
She left in the car and stated she was headed toward Grand
Rapids when she eventually saw the police behind her. Youth A
reported she had covered the dash camera with a face mask in
the car. The police followed her for about 45 minutes before the
car became disabled and stopped moving. She stated she initially
refused to get out of the car, but the officers pulled guns on her
and pulled her out of the car. She reported she was not injured as
a result of being pulled out of the car. Youth A also reported she
has stolen a car over 10 times in the past and has had prior
charges for car theft. She denied she and Staff 1 had any
conversation about her stealing the car. Youth A confirmed she is
currently on probation for stealing a car and attempted vehicular
homicide. Youth A advised she does not want to return to
Footprints and would prefer to remain at Ingham County Youth
Department. Youth A denied she had planned to steal the agency
vehicle.
On 06/14/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the Chief
Administrator (CA) and Program Manager (PM) at Footprints. The
DHHS specialist was also present. CA and PM were advised a
special investigation was being initiated. CA advised she saw
Youth A at the detention center yesterday and she alleged Staff 1
2

gave her the agency keys, the work credit card and her cell phone
to hold while they were in the movies. CA also reported later
Youth A indicated the keys were in the cup holder. CA also
recalled another resident in the program had previously told staff
that Youth A was talking about going AWOL and taking the
agency vehicle. CA advised on the day of the incident,
06/10/2023, she was contacted by Staff 1 around 6:45 PM and
informed Youth A had stolen the vehicle while they were at the
movies. CA reported Youth A had stolen a vehicle at least two
times prior to being placed at Footprints. She further stated
“briefings” are held with the staff to provide information regarding
why youth enter care and other areas of concern. CA reported
each youth has a binder on site that maintains information
regarding the youth. It includes information about court hearings,
consents, parental information, medical information, any concerns,
etc. The binders are available for staff review and they are
responsible for reviewing the information in the binders. Youth A’s
binder was reviewed, and it included a face sheet that
documented the following reasons for referral: problems
respecting authority, violence, vandalism, lying, history of self-
harm, poor behavior in school, gang involvement, truancy, drug or
alcohol abuse, family relationship problems, stealing and
manipulation. The binder also included information regarding
multiple charges including unlawful driving of a motor vehicle. CA
identified the following Footprints policies that were not followed
during the outing: Staff belongings are to be kept on person and
Resident Supervision which indicates Footprints must have a
minimum of one staff in direct line of sight during all youth awake
hours.
On 06/14/2023 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 1 at
Footprints. The DHHS specialist was also present. Staff 1
advised she has worked at Footprints in the past and this is her
third employment episode with the agency and has been back
since January 2023. Her current position is a youth advisor.
Staff 1 reported on 06/10/2023, she and Youth A went to the
movies at Regal Theater at the Lansing Mall. They arrived around
4:40 PM. Staff 1 recalled she was wearing leggings and a long
sleeved shirt and did not have any pockets. She reported she
placed the vehicle keys in the cupholder between her and Youth
A. She stated her wallet was near the keys and at some point
Youth A handed it to her and she placed it in her lap. Staff 1
reported about 35 minutes into the movie, Youth A requested to
go to the restroom, she was provided permission and told to return
in five minutes. Staff 1 confirmed this was the second time Youth
A asked to go to the restroom. She returned in about 5 minutes
3

the first time, but Staff 1 stated she noticed she had not come
back the second time within 10 minutes so she went to the
restroom to find her. She reported she did not see Youth A
anywhere, so she asked the staff at the theater if they had seen
her, which they had not. She recalled the keys were in the cup
holder when Youth A did not return from the bathroom. Staff 1
stated she then went to the parking lot and noticed the agency
vehicle was gone and she contacted the police and her
supervisor. Staff 1 reported prior to leaving for the movies, she
and Youth A had dropped off recycling for the home and when
they returned to the home she had not initially taken the keys out
of the car, but then noticed and retrieved them. Youth A said to
her “I wouldn’t trust me with those keys” in a joking manner. Staff
1 stated she felt Youth A was referencing her history of stealing
cars. Staff 1 confirmed she was aware of Youth A’s history of
stealing cars and going AWOL from placements. Staff 1
acknowledged her awareness of the agency policy regarding
supervision and stated she failed to follow this policy when she did
not go to the restroom with Youth A.
On 07/11/2023 a DHHS Closing Case conference was held via
video conference. The DHHS specialist reported that Staff 1 would
have a confirmed case for improper supervision.
Documents Reviewed:
Footprints Incident Report – Summary: On Saturday June 10th,
Footprints staff took youth to the movie at the Regal Cinemas. During
the movie, youth requested to go to the bathroom and was allowed. Five
minutes went by and staff went to look for youth. When she was not
found in the bathroom, staff requested cinema employee assistance.
After not being located, staff checked the parking lot and noticed the
company vehicle was missing. Staff had left the vehicle keys in the
cupholder connected to her movie theater chair. Staff contacted Eaton
County Sheriff 's Office to notify them of the stolen vehicle.
Staff 1 Employee File – No discipline in employee file for this
employment episode. Staff 1 did receive a verbal warning during her
previous employment episode in 2020 for improper distribution of
medication to youth. Staff 1 was provided with employee handbook that
includes policy on staff belongings and supervision on 01/23/23.
Footprints Policy and Procedures – Re: Staff Belongings the
policy indicates that purses, cell phones, keys, etc. must be kept on your
person or locked in the office. At no time is a youth allowed to access
staff belongings. Re: Supervision the policy indicates that Footprints
must have a minimum of one staff in direct line of sight of youth during
all awake hours.
4

Police Report – Summary: On 06/10/2023 at 7:00 pm, notification was
received that Eaton County was attempting to locate a stolen vehicle.
The White Traverse was located, and then exited the highway. A stop
sign and several red lights were ignored by the driver. The vehicle
reached speeds of 90 miles per hour and then increased to 102 miles
per hour while being pursued by the Deputy with lights and sirens. The
pursuit was terminated near East Peck Lake Road. The vehicle was
then spotted to be entering the on ramp to I 96 at South State Road
while On Star was attempting to terminate the vehicle. It was terminated
by On Star and youth was arrested and was lodged at the Juvenile
Detention Center.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, it was found that the agency
was in non-compliance with licensing rule 4109-1C. The staff
failed to follow agency policies regarding supervision of the youth
in the program. Staff 1 failed to maintain direct line-sight as
required by the policy when allowing Youth A to go to the
bathroom unattended. The staff also failed to follow agency
policies regarding Staff Belongings as Staff 1 failed to ensure her
personal belongings (Agency Keys and wallet) were properly
secured and out of the reach of children.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established:

Type

Investigation During a conference call on 07/11/2023, DHHS specialist reported
there was a preponderance of evidence and Staff 1 will have a
confirmed case.
Analysis Staff member lacks the ability to perform job duties.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan,
it is recommended that the current license status be continued.
